title: Landscape drivers of connectivity for a forest rodent in a coffee agroecosystem
abstract: Context The majority of remaining tropical forests exist as fragments embedded in a matrix of agricultural production. Understanding the effects of these agricultural landscapes on species dispersal is crucial in the development of successful conservation planning. Objective The objective of this study was to examine the influence of five landscape features within a coffee agroecosystem (i.e., slope, elevation, streams, riparian effect, and tree cover) on Heteromys desmarestianus goldmani gene flow. We expected that landscape variables linked to more intense agricultural management (e.g., low tree cover, riparian effect) would reduce gene flow in H. d. goldmani.

abstract.text: Context The majority of remaining tropical forests exist as fragments embedded in a matrix of agricultural production. Understanding the effects of these agricultural landscapes on species dispersal is crucial in the development of successful conservation planning. Objective The objective of this study was to examine the influence of five landscape features within a coffee agroecosystem (i.e., slope, elevation, streams, riparian effect, and tree cover) on Heteromys desmarestianus goldmani gene flow. We expected that landscape variables linked to more intense agricultural management (e.g., low tree cover, riparian effect) would reduce gene flow in H. d. goldmani.

body_text.text: Methods This study was conducted in a 4 km 9 2 km area within the coffee growing region of Soconusco in Chiapas, Mexico. We used 12 microsatellite markers to calculate individual-based estimates of gene flow as a measure of dispersal. We used resistance surface modelling, using Resis-tanceGA (Peterman in Methods Ecol Evol 9:1638 -1647 , 2018 to identify if any of the landscape features analyzed explained the patterns of gene flow. Results Our results showed patterns of population structure and weak isolation-by-distance, as found previously for H. d. goldmani by Otero Jiménez et al. (Conserv Genet 19:495-499, 2018) . Slope and tree cover were the two landscape features that could best explain gene flow patterns. More specifically, intermediate slopes and tree cover represent the lowest resistance to gene flow for H. d. goldmani and, thus, have a role in promoting gene flow in this species. Conclusion This study highlights the potential of integrating molecular and landscape data to explore population connectivity of elusive species, such as terrestrial small mammals. Our study adds to the growing body of literature in landscape genetics by demonstrating that a rodent species shows population structure at a small scale resulting from landscape factors linked to agricultural management.

The majority of landscapes are characterized by a highly heterogeneous structure. This structure can be of natural (e.g., humidity, topography) or anthropogenic (e.g., agriculture, urbanization) origin. From the point of view of an organism, some landscape characteristics will support the organism's survival and reproduction, while others will restrict it. Areas that promote the survival and reproduction of organisms are known as habitat, while the matrix is the area in between habitable areas for a particular species.

The matrix can vary in quality depending on the species in question and the land cover represented in the area (Perfecto et al. 2010 ). High quality matrices will promote species movement across the landscape, while low-quality matrices will impede movement. Understanding the influence of matrix composition on population connectivity is of great importance in our current world where the landscape is increasingly fragmented due to human perturbations (Perfecto et al. 2010; Haddad et al. 2015) . Agricultural production is one of the major drivers of land cover change, which now comprises approximately half of the Earth's land surface (Hooke et al. 2012) . This has led most tropical forests to exist as fragments embedded in a matrix of agricultural production.

Frequently, agriculture is viewed in opposition to biodiversity conservation (Perfecto and Vandermeer 2008) . However, within the agricultural matrix we can find management practices that vary greatly in the level of intensification, from high crop diversity and low external inputs (e.g., organic or traditional production) to systems with a single crop species and increased use of external inputs (i.e., pesticides, herbicides; Perfecto et al. 2010 ). Because of this variation in management, we do not expect all agricultural lands to influence species movement equally. By identifying which agricultural practices facilitate dispersal we can maintain productive landscapes while also preventing species extinctions. However, few studies have evaluated the effect of different management practices on species dispersal at a fine scale (for an example see Flores-Manzanero et al. 2018) .

This study explores the way in which different landscape features influence patterns of gene flow among individuals of the forest dwelling rodent, Heteromys desmarestianus goldmani, in order to understand how matrix quality influences connectivity in a landscape dominated by coffee production. Rodents are the most diverse group of mammals, playing a variety of ecological roles, such as seed dispersers, herbivores, predators, prey, disease vectors, and ecosystem engineers. As members of diverse food webs (Dickman 1999) they are frequently thought to be key elements of ecosystems (Brown and Heske 1990; Davidson and Lightfoot 2006) .

In an earlier study examining H. d. goldmani genetic population structure, Otero Jiménez et al. (2018) found limitations to gene flow within a coffee agroecosystem composed of forest fragments and farms with diverse management practices. Their results showed distinct genetic clusters that could not be explained by geographic distance between samples (i.e., isolation-by-distance). Our study builds on Otero Jiménez et al. (2018) findings by extending the sampling of H. d. goldmani across coffee farms and by including an additional two forest fragments in an effort to identify landscape features that are restricting or promoting gene flow in this agricultural landscape. We collected genetic data from 12 microsatellite markers and land cover data derived from satellite images from five landscape features (i.e., slope, elevation, streams, riparian effect, and tree cover) to examine their influence on H. d. goldmani gene flow. We expect landscape features related to agricultural management (i.e., tree cover and riparian effect), to have a stronger effect on gene flow than topographical features (e.g., slope, elevation). More specifically, we predict proximity to rivers or streams (i.e., riparian effect) and high canopy cover to promote dispersal (i.e., gene flow) of H. d. goldmani. Otero Jiménez et al. (2018) reported that H. d. goldmani individuals found in the high intensity coffee farm clustered along streams edges. We expect these areas to serve as refugia or corridors for the mice. These areas have higher tree cover than surrounding coffee production and can provide resources needed to survive within the farms as well as protection from predators.

cite_spans.text: H. d. goldmani. Otero Jiménez et al. (2018)

body_text.text: The spiny pocket mouse, Heteromys desmarestianus, is a rodent that inhabits moist forest habitats from southern Mexico to Panama (Fleming 1974) . It is the most abundant small mammal in these regions (Klinger 2007) and has a home range of 100 m 2 (Fleming 1974) , which is small for a terrestrial rodent. Studies conducted in Costa Rica have shown that the diet of H. desmarestianus mainly consists of palm nuts and other seeds (Fleming 1983) , making this rodent an important seed disperser in tropical regions (DeMattia et al. 2004) . Based on genetic and morphological data Heteromys desmarestianus is considered a species complex to which H. d. goldmani is a member (Rogers and Gonzalez 2010) .

Coffee production in Latin America represents an ideal system for studying the effects of different management practices. In this region, coffee is produced in a variety of ways that follow an intensification gradient (Otero-Jimenez et al. 2018; Moguel and Toledo 1999) . It is common to find several of these management practices represented in small areas. For this reason, we chose to do our study in the tropical montane region of Soconusco in Chiapas, Mexico (Fig. 1a ). This area is dominated by coffee production that varies in management intensity, ranging from rustic to unshaded monocultures with forest patches scattered between them (Fig. 1b) .

The three coffee farms included in this study are identified as having low, medium and high management intensity based on the Moguel and Toledo (1999) classification system. The low intensity coffee farm was certified Smithsonian Bird FriendlyÒ coffee production at the time of the study ( Fig. 2c ) and is characterized by endemic shade trees and understory trees. The medium intensity farm is an organic shaded commercial polyculture coffee farm (i.e., no synthetic herbicide, pesticide or fertilizer use). Most shade trees in this farm are nitrogen fixing Inga trees that are found alongside Tabaeuia, Yucca and Ocotea species (Iverson 2015; Fig. 2b ). Additionally, there are fruit trees such as guava and avocado throughout the farm (Iverson 2015) . The high intensity coffee farm is closest to sun coffee, dominated by intensely pruned Inga trees (Iverson 2015; Fig. 2a ). This farm also uses synthetic fertilizers, herbicides, and pesticides. Farms included in the study have been producing coffee for 60-100 years. Although management practices vary over time, these farms have had similar management practices for at least the past 20 years (Perfecto and Vandermeer 2002 ).

H. d. goldmani samples were collected from 2012 to 2015. We used 136 samples previously collected in the region from 2012 to 2014 (Otero Jiménez et al. 2018) and added 29 new samples from 2015 with the goal of reaching continuous sampling across the study site. Ear tissue samples from H. d. goldmani were collected across a coffee agroecosystem composed of three forest fragments and the three coffee farms described earlier (Fig. 1b) . To facilitate continuous animal collection across this complex landscape we sampled an area of approximately 4 km 9 2 km ( Fig. 1b) , by placing traps in 100 m transects following roads and trails within the farms and the forest fragments, following the methodology of Otero Jiménez et al. (2018) . Two Sherman traps were placed every 10 m at the base of a tree or log on either side of the transect line. Transects were moved every night within the farms or forest fragments. While equal trapping effort was put into each of the areas sampled (i.e., 3 forest fragments and 3 coffee farms), we were not able to obtain ideal continuous sampling. Ear tissue samples were preserved in 20% DMSO buffer saturated with NaCl at room temperature until extraction (i.e., 1-8 weeks). Mice were captured using 22.9 cm 9 7.6 cm 9 8.9 cm Sherman live traps. Sex and GPS coordinates for each individual sample were recorded. Animals were handled in accordance with the University of Michigan's Committee on Use and Care of Animals.

DNA Extraction-In order to obtain population genetic data, we extracted DNA from 165 adult and juvenile H. d. goldmani ear tissue samples within our sampling area. Genetic data were obtained using the 12 species-specific microsatellite markers developed by Otero Jiménez et al. (2018-HET1, HET4, HET23, HET27, HET32, HET34, HET37, HET42, HET41, HET46, HET56, HET57). All loci were polymorphic in all sampling locations. Loci were tested for the presence of scoring errors and null alleles using Micro-Checker (Van Oosterhout et al. 2004) . We tested for deviations from Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium (HWE) and for linkage disequilibrium at all loci and collecting sites (e.g., coffee farms of different intensities and forest fragment) using Arlequin 3.5.1.3 (Excoffier and Lischer 2010) . Bonferroni corrections were applied to determine significance of HWE and linkage results. We estimated relatedness (r) within and between sites to check that individuals sampled were not siblings. We calculated pair-wise values of r (Ritland and Lynch 1999) for all individuals using GenAlEx (Peakall and Smouse 2012) .

Isolation by Distance (IBD)-To assess the influence of geographic distance on the observed estimates of gene flow we calculated isolation by distance (IBD). Individual pairwise Euclidian distance and codominant genotypic distance were computed using Genalex (Peakall and Smouse 2012) . These values were used to measure the correlation between genetic distance of all sampled individuals and Euclidean distance with a simple Mantel test in Genalex (Peakall and Smouse 2012) . Significance (95% CI) was calculated using random permutations. In addition, we estimated a Mantel correlogram based on 100 m distance classes considering the home range reported for Heteromys (Fleming 1974) . Significance for each distance class was calculated using Spearman correlation based on 10,000 permutations using the ecodist R package.

Population Structure Analyses-The coffee agroecological landscape was expected to have some effect on the dispersal of the mice (Otero Jiménez et al. 2018) . To corroborate that genetic structure within our samples followed patterns found in Otero Jiménez et al. 2018, we estimated the number of genetic units b Fig. 1 Maps of the study region; a shows the location of our study site within the state of Chiapas, Mexico, and b highlights trails (in red) used for sampling and the location of streams (in blue). The locations of mice sampled are indicated by circles (K) and the locations of breaks in gene flow that define these clusters using Geneland (Guillot 2008 ), a Bayesian clustering method (See Supplementary Material for more details). For the genetic clusters identified by Geneland, we measured genetic diversity by quantifying observed heterozygosity (HO), expected heterozygosity (H E ), fixation index (F IS ) and allelic richness (A R ) using GenAlEx (Peakall and Smouse 2012) . To assess differences in genetic diversity between clusters we used values for each measure (i.e., F IS , H E , H O , A R ) for each locus at each cluster and conducted a bootstrap analysis of the mean with replacement in R for 10,000 iterations. To assess genetic differentiation between groups we calculated pairwise F ST (Wright 1951) using Arlequin (Excoffier and Lischer 2010) .

Landscape variables-Within a 4 km long (E-W) by 2 km wide area (Fig. 1c) , we tested the significance of five landscape features we hypothesized could influence dispersal: (1) tree cover (TC), (2) slope (S), (3) elevation (E), (4) riparian effect (RE), and (5) streams (STR ; Table 1 ). Slope and elevation are the most common variables analyzed in landscape resistance analysis (Zeller et al. 2012) and are known to influence connectivity. Rivers and streams have been known to serve as barriers to movement for small mammals (Savidge 1973; Wolff 1999; Bohdal et al. 2016) . Tree cover and riparian effects are the two agricultural management related features in our study. High tree cover has been linked to increased species richness and density of small mammals (Munshi-South et al. 2016; Caudill and Rice 2016). We included riparian effect (i.e., distance from stream) because these areas are usually steeper and tend to be unmanaged in the farms, potentially serving as important corridors or habitat for wildlife. Landscape features were quantified using products derived from Google Earth aerial imagery and a 20 m resolution digital elevation model (DEM). Land cover was digitized manually using the heads-up digitizing method (Bolstad 2016) to map polygons of similar levels of tree cover discernable at a 1:2000 scale. Land cover was classified using a scale from 1 to 6 which corresponds to the amount of tree cover, not taking into account species identity: (1) no high vegetation cover (open), (2) sun coffee plantation (no tree cover), (3) 25% tree cover coffee plantation, (4) 50% tree cover coffee plantation, (5) 75% tree cover coffee plantation, and (6) 100% tree cover (Fig. S1 ). Slope and elevation layers were developed from the DEM using appropriate geoprocessing tools (Fig. S1 ). Streams were delineated from the DEM by calculating flow accumulation and classifying any cells above a value of 100 as a stream including only streams that have water flow year round (Fig. S1) . The flow accumulation is the calculation of upstream area for every raster cell in our analysis area (Jenson and Domingue 1988) . This calculation does not account for seasonality in water levels. We created the riparian effect layer by calculating a n Euclidean distance raster from stream locations, which we used to represent lower resistance with closer proximity to a stream (Fig. S1 ). Digitization and DEM raster processing was performed with ArcGIS 10.3.1 (ESRI 2015).

Resistance Surfaces-Each landscape variable layer was converted to a raster map representing the assumed resistance to movement of each variable to H. d. goldmani (Table 1, Fig. S1 ). These predictions of landscape effects on movement were based on the available natural history research of H. d. goldmani and other members of the Heteromys genus (Fleming 1974 (Fleming , 1983 Martínez-Gallardo and Sánchez-Cordero 1993; Klinger 2007) . Landscape surfaces were rescaled to the finest possible resolution (20 m 9 20 m) to reflect the hypothetical perceived scale of resistance for H. d. goldmani.

Most studies evaluating the effects of landscape resistance on genetic population connectivity rely on expert opinion to describe the relationship between landscape variables and species movement (Zeller et al. 2012) . We used the method developed by Peterman et al. (2014) to optimize our resistance surfaces to address concerns of analyses based on expert opinion. For example, many studies using expert opinion to develop landscape resistance models treat expert opinion as empirical data, when it is not, thus making it difficult to evaluate performance (Zeller et al. 2012) . In general, it is difficult to describe accurately the ecological processes being modelled in resistance analyses, and even if the processes are known, there is no guarantee that they will have significant influence on gene flow (Peterman 2018) . Peterman et al.'s (2014) optimization approach relies on a genetic algorithm to explore the parameter space, which seeks to maximize the relationship between pairwise landscape resistance distances (i.e., landscape variables) and pairwise genetic distances without any a priori assumptions (Peterman 2018) . The optimization was done using the R package ResistanceGA (Peterman 2018) . Landscape surfaces were optimized in two steps: (1) single resistance surface optimization, and (2) combined (i.e., multi-) surface optimization (Fig. S1 ). For the first step we optimized each landscape surface independently, using the commuteDistance function exploring resistance values up to 2500 using an 8 neighbor joining scheme to measure connectivity (Fig. S1) . The com-muteDistance function, which calculates the commute distance or the time it takes for an individual to move from point a to point b in a particular landscape (van Etten 2017). Our dependent variable was genetic distance measured as a r (Rousset 2000) , calculated using Genepop (Rousset 2008) , and our predictor variables were the landscape resistance values. If more than one H. d. goldmani individual was sampled within the 20 m 9 20 m area, a single H. d. goldmani sample was randomly selected for this analysis. For continuous landscape variables (i.e., slope, elevation and riparian effect) we tested nine possible transformations for the resistance relationship between both variables (i.e., linear, monomolecular, reverse monomolecular, inverse monomolecular, inverse-reverse monomolecular, Ricker, reverse Ricker, inverse Ricker, inverse-reverse Ricker). Additionally, we included pair-wise geographic distance of samples as our null model. We conducted three independent optimization runs for each of the landscape variables to ensure results were robust.

The optimal resistance surface was identified using the Akaike Information Criterion (AIC), determined by a linear mixed effects model with a maximum likelihood population effects parameterization (MLPE; Peterman 2018). The covariate structure in MLPE was specifically designed to account for nonindependence of values within pairwise distance matrices (Clarke et al. 2002; Van Strien et al. 2012) and the random effect in these models indicates the dependencies between each of the pairwise distances. We then conducted a bootstrap analysis in which 75% of the samples were randomly selected without replacement and each surface was fit to the subset of samples to control for potential bias in our analysis. For each subset of samples, the models' average rank, average weight and percentage that a surface was selected (top rank) were calculated with 10,000 iterations.

Before we continued to the second optimization step for combined surfaces, we conducted a Spearman coefficient correlation test in R between the top commute distance matrices of all optimized single surfaces that performed better than geographic distance alone. We selected variables that showed small to moderate correlation (p \ 0.49), to avoid including correlated variables in the combined surface model.

For the second optimization step we performed the combined surface optimization with surfaces that showed moderate to low correlation (Fig. S1 ). Parameters for the combined surface optimization were the same as for the first optimization step. Additionally, we performed bootstrap model selection using the same parameters as for the single surface optimization in order to obtain the average rank, average model weight and the top ranked model for individual and combined surfaces. Optimization R script was adapted from Flores-Manzareno et al. (2018) to conduct this analysis.

We found evidence of linkage disequilibrium at one locus (HET-41) across multiple sampling sites. This locus was eliminated from the data set for all further analyses. Micro-Checker found no evidence of scoring errors but did imply null alleles for locus HET-46 (P \ 0.0001). All loci were polymorphic in all sampling locations. A total of 97 alleles were scored at 11 loci in all H. d. goldmani samples with an average of seven alleles per locus (range 3-13; Table S1 ). Primer and locus information can be found in Otero Jiménez et al. (2018) . Results for the Lynch and Ritland (1999) relatedness estimator show values of r \ 0.5 within and between sites (Table S2) indicating samples were not taken from members of the same litter.

Results from genetic clustering analysis revealed six distinct genetic clusters ( Fig. S2 ; Table S3 ). These results support the clustering patterns found in Otero Jiménez et al. (2018) where individuals sampled closer to the middle forest fragment were classified as the same population, and individuals from localities further east or west of the forest fragment, constitute separate clusters (Fig. S2) . In addition, this study included samples from two other forest fragments not sampled in Otero Jiménez et al. (2018). Our results show that samples from each of these fragments represent distinct genetic clusters (Fig. S2) . We did not find any significant difference in genetic diversity measures between the clusters (i.e., F IS , H E , H O , AR; Fig. S3 ). Pair wise genetic differentiation (F ST ) between clusters was statistically significant with values ranging from 0.01 to 0.05 (Table S4) . These results are similar to those found previously in Otero Jiménez et al. (2018).
Isolation by distance results show significant but weak positive correlation between genetic distance and geographic distance for all samples (Mantel r = 0.11, P = 0.002; Fig. 3a) .

The mantel correlogram showed significant positive relationship between genetic and geographic distance for four distance classes \ 500 m ( Fig. 3b ; Table S5 ). Mantel r for these distance classes ranged from 0.028 to 0.078, with the 100 m distance class having the highest value. Additionally, it identified five distance classes with a weak but significant negative relationship ( Fig. 3b; Table S5 ), which we interpret as having no biological significance for the species.

Model selection results show that the slope (S) resistance surface was the best-supported model (43.05% of the times based on 10,000 bootstrap replicates, AIC = -13,067; Table 2 ). From all the transformations tested, Inverse-Reverse Ricker function was the best fit for our genetic distance data (Fig. 4a) . The next best supported resistance surface was tree cover (TC) (33.75% of the times, AIC = -13,067; Table 2 ). Additionally, the linear mixed effect model identified both variables (i.e., slope and cover) as significant predictors of genetic distance. Streams and riparian effect ranked as the top models explaining genetic distance 11.71% and 10.49% of the time (AIC = -13,064 and -13,063), of the variation in genetic distance data than distance alone (Table 2 ; Fig. 4c ). Elevation had poor performance (0.88%, AIC = -13,064.07; Table 2 ; Fig. 4b ). It was the lowest ranking model other than Euclidean distance (Table 2) .

We tested for correlations between all layers, except riparian effect, using Spearman's tau. All surfaces showed some degree of correlation between each other. Seven out of the nine layer pairs showed strong ([ 0.50 Spearman tau; Table S6 ) correlation and three layer pairs showed evidence of moderate correlation (S ? TC, S ? STR, S ? RE; Table S6 ). For the next optimization step, we chose to perform a combined surface optimization analysis with a single combined surface of slope and tree cover, along with all other single surface variables. Because tree cover (TC), streams (STR) and riparian effect (RE) had strong correlations with each other we only created a single combined surface of S ? TC. The lower correlation between tree cover and slope could be explained by the differences in management practices between the medium and high intensity coffee farms. Steeper areas in the medium intensity coffee farm are more likely to be left unmanaged, while in the high intensity farm steeper areas are included in coffee production. Results showed the combined surface to be the best supported model at 45.51%, followed by slope (21.76%; AIC = -13,069.23) and tree cover (13.55%; AIC = -13,069.43; Table 3 ).

This study was designed to search for potential relationships between landscape features and the limitations to gene flow found in Otero Jiménez et al. 2018for the forest rodent H. d. goldmani in a coffee agroecosystem. Our results examining population structure with an increased sample size (from n = 136 Otero Jiménez et al. 2018 to n = 165 this study) confirmed earlier patterns including a weak but significant increase in genetic differentiation with increasing geographic distance between individuals. Of the five landscape variables sampled, slope is the one with the strongest influence on genetic distance, followed by tree cover. The permeability of areas with higher slopes can vary in the landscape with the level of management intensity. We found that intermediate slopes (i.e., 30-40% slope) had the lowest levels of resistance for Heteromys with increasing resistance at the two extremes. This could be due to the fact that flat (low slope) areas are used for coffee production and the mice are not able to disperse as easily through this landscape. However, as slope increases, harvesting and management of coffee is more difficult and the land is not as intensely managed, creating a better environment for the mice until it reaches a certain threshold where it becomes too steep for mice to disperse readily. We found that our results are supported by studies done on other mammal species, where slope was an important predictor for richness and density (Carver 2010; Russo et al. 2016; Keeley et al. 2016 ).

The best model of the tree cover surface showed that intermediate levels of tree cover (50-75%) are the most permeable for Heteromys, followed by high tree cover ([ 75%) . Areas with 25% tree cover were classified with the highest resistance (Fig. S4) . Tree cover or canopy cover has been identified as an . The Caudill and Rice (2016) study on rodent diversity in a similar coffee system highlighted the importance of canopy cover for rodent species richness and density. In addition, higher tree cover could be correlated to higher food resource availability (i.e., seeds) for H. d. goldmani, which could be a factor driving the higher gene flow in areas with 50-75% tree cover. One reason why landscape resistance might be higher in areas with 100% tree cover, could be that a slightly more open canopy allows for more diversity of understory plant species increasing availability of food resources for Heteromys

. Surprisingly, open areas and sun coffee, which are the smallest percentage of cover type in the area (Fig. S4 ), were classified with low resistance values. It is not clear what could be driving these patterns. One reason could be the absence of samples near or within these areas. Integrating samples from rodents in these open areas would increase our understanding the influence of this areas to gene flow. Consistent with other studies, our findings suggest that tree cover is essential for maintaining rodent population connectivity in agroecosystems. We expected riparian effect to be one of the main variables explaining gene flow. Our results generally support our prediction, with riparian effect ranking as the third or fourth best supported model. However, the streams layer performed similarly well, suggesting that areas near streams (riparian effect) and streams facilitate Heteromys gene flow. This pattern is opposite to what we expected and may be due to the spatial scale of the surfaces (20 m 9 20 m) being too large to capture the influences of streams on Heteromys dispersal. As a consequence, both the riparian vegetation and stream layer may be representing use of areas near streams as dispersal corridors. These results could also be linked to resource availability. There is a higher diversity of vegetation (i.e., non-coffee plants) found near streams and, thus, these areas may provide important food sources for Heteromys.

In summary, our results show that H. d. goldmani gene flow is influenced by landscape variables, more than by geographic distance. Our study had several limitations that could have influenced the strength of the patterns observed. One of these limitations was sampling; we worked within active coffee farms and in a highly mountainous region where certain areas were inaccessible for trapping, thus limiting our ability to achieve continuous sampling. In addition, sampling in areas with little to no tree cover resulted in very low to no trap success. This pattern could mean that Heteromys does not use regions of low tree cover or that it exists at very low density and trapping effort was not sufficient. Secondly, our landscape data were limited in grain by the resolution of the satellite images and the digital elevation model used, which was 20 m 9 20 m at its finest. Studies have demonstrated the importance of spatial scale in determining the relationship between landscape variables and population structure (Zeller et al. 2012; Oyler-McCance et al. 2013) . Since our project examined rodent populations a finer resolution of landscape features would have been preferable, however, because 20 m is still smaller than the estimated home range of Heteromys, this scale was able to provide some valuable insight. We hope that with technological advancements collecting these data at finer scales will become more affordable and accessible in the near future. We expect that with finer scale data we will find stronger relationships between the landscape variables analyzed and the genetic structure of Heteromys.

Finally, while population structure and connectivity are influenced by many variables, we limited our study to five of these variables. We note that there are many others with the potential to be of greater influence. For example, humidity has been explored as an important variable in small mammal studies (Flores-Manzanero et al. 2018) and could be an important measure for H. d. goldmani because it is a forest dwelling rodent.

This study provides an example of how genetic and landscape data can inform research on population connectivity in agricultural systems at a small scale. From the literature we know that tropical rodents play an important role in the ecosystem and their conservation is important for the maintenance of other species (Fischer et al. 2011) and, yet, they are negatively impacted by fragmentation, land cover and habitat loss (Blois et al. 2010) . Our findings add important insights to the literature on tropical rodents and their responses to anthropogenic land use changes. Our results highlight how agricultural production (e.g., tree cover) in coffee agroecosystems can be managed to promote and sustain rodent populations, thus emphasizing the potential role agriculture can play in maintaining biodiversity and connectivity in tropical landscapes.
Landscape Ecol (2020) 35:1249-1261

back_matter.text: Acknowledgements We thank Dr. Consuelo Lorenzo and El Colegio de la Frontera Sur-San Cristobal in Chiapas, Mexico for their help in sample collection. Thanks to Dr. Carlos J. Anderson for his valuable comments on the manuscript and support with statistical analysis and Dr. M. Raquel Marchan Rivadeneira for assistance with genetic analysis. We thank the managers, farmers and owners of Finca Irlanda and Finca Hamburgo in Chiapas, Mexico for allowing us to conduct this study and for their support with fieldwork. This work received financial support from the University of Michigan Center for Latin America and Caribbean Studies Tinker Field Research Grant and the University of Michigan Rackham Graduate School.Beatriz Otero Jiménez was supported in part by University of Michigan Genetics Training Program (T32-GM07544).

FIGREF1.text: Representative images of coffee farms and forest fragments sampled: a high intensity coffee management showing open canopy, b medium intensity coffee farm, c low intensity coffee farms and d forest fragment

FIGREF3.text: Isolation by Distance (IBD) results: a Isolation by distance for all samples of H. d. goldmani, each diamond represents a pair of individuals and b Mantel correlogram for geographic (Euclidian) and genetic (a r ) distances calculated at 100 m distance classes for H. d. goldmani. Significant values (p \ 0.05) are shown in black. Their corresponding Mantel r values are inTable S4

FIGREF4.text: Fig. 4Response curves for a slope, b elevation and c riparian effect of single surface optimization using genetic distance for H. d. goldmani. Bars along the plots represent the distribution of resistance values important component to promote movement and species richness of terrestrial rodents(Lomolino and Perault 2001;Santos-Filho et al. 2012;Caudill and Rice 2016) and other groups (birds;Martensen et al.  2012, amphibians;Popescu and Hunter 2011)

TABREF0.text: Expected H. d. goldmani resistance to movement for each landscape variable
TABREF0.content:
Landscape variableVariable typeExpected resistance
Euclidean distanceIsolation by distance. Greater resistance when further apart
ElevationContinuousGreater resistance as the mice move away from the optimal elevation
SlopeContinuousGreater resistance as the percent slope increases
Riparian effectContinuousGreater resistance further from stream edge
Tree coverCategoricalGreater resistance with lower tree cover
StreamsCategoricalStreams as barriers to movement

TABREF1.text: Model selection results for the generalized linear mixed-effects models optimized on genetic distance (a r ) for H. d. goldmani. K is the number of parameters for each model
